bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Lemuel S. Reed, February 23, 1896

div1.p: Reed provides genealogical information on the Reed family. Emilie Lawrence Reed has been with her mother, Hanna Rea Lawrence, after the death of Emilie's youngest brother, Edward F. Lawrence. Reed also comments on the war spirit in Washington.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Lemuel S. Reed, February 23, 1896

opener.dateline:
No. 5 Cooke Place,
Georgetown, D.C,
February 23,'96

div1.p:
Your last letter re=
ceived some days ago, & was
extremely interesting to me- I have
put it aside, for the time, as I am
so busily engaged on other things,
but will investigate its contents
more thoroughly after I get a
little leisure- while I think of
it, let me tell you that all of
the Colonial Records of Perquimans a, starting from
the date of George Durant's grant,
down to this date, are in a per-
fect state of preservation--Mr
Joshua Whedbee, of Hertford,
assures me of this fact, through
Cousin Bettie Reed's letters-
I found several volumes of the
Colonial Records of N.C. in the War
Department- In these the Records
of Perquimans Co. N.C. form a
very prominent part- Mr Whedbee
says that these Records show that
William Reed, Wilson Reed's father,
was the son of Joseph Reed- As
your grandfather & William Reed must
have been brothers, he, too, was the
son of Joseph Reed- The latter
married a daughter of George
Durant. Jr, the son of the original
George Durant- Joseph Reed was
the Son of Tully Reed, & he the Son
of Christopher, Reed, whose tomb
is still on the Leigh farm, now
owned by Albert Grandy, of Norfolk.
Mr Whedbee says the records are
perfectly plain and I have no reason
to doubt his word- In order to be
absolutely assured of these things, I
shall in May go down & see for
myself- I was so sorry to hear
that you had had a severe cold.
These attacks have been quite
prevalent in Washington-so many
have been confined in-doors with
something like Influenza-

Emily left here, Friday evening, to at-
tend the funeral services of her
youngest brother, Eddie Lawrence,
who died in Norfolk, Thursday last-
Had Cerebral Meningitis- She
will stay with her mother a week
or so, as the old lady is dreadfully
broken-hearted over Eddie's death.
Little daughter is house-keeper
during her mother's absence,
I trust that this cold snap didn't
reach Prince Edward County- It was
colder than ginger here - down
to nearly zero- The war spirit
seems to be dying out, so that
I probably shall not need the
services of those P.E. Mountaineers!
Tell Mr Douglas to keep his blade
sharpened, for the present peace-
ful aspect may take a sudden
turn, in which case I shall ex-
pect him to promptly rally the
“boys”! Think we could charge the
Britishers rather gracefully, pro-
vided Mrs. Elam won't object-
Take good care of yourself & have
that bolt repaired belonging to the
back door of the Hall-

Much love to Ma, Annie
Mrs. Elam & Mr Douglas-
